properties.name: Edmonton Centre
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamAfter three straight failures, the Tories have stopped running retired professor Don Weideman in the city1s core against Liberal stalwart Laurie Blakeman. This time, they1re fielding consultant Bill Donahue, while the NDP have inner-city teacher Deron Bilous.

properties.name: Edmonton-Beverly-Clareview
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamRay Martin, the NDP1s former leader, won easily last time to end his 11-year legislature hiatus. But this may become a three-way race. Tony Vandermeer, ex-Tory MLA in nearby Edmonton-Manning, wants back in, too. Liberal Dawit Isaac, an Eritrea-born evangelical church leader, has dazzled fellow Grits with his organizing prowess.

properties.name: Edmonton-Calder
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamDavid Eggen (NDP) worked the neighbourhoods hard to win in 2004, and hasn1t stopped since. Safety manager Doug Elniski (PC) and CN Rail official Jim Kane (Liberal) are both pushing to win this working-class riding. Last three elections here have gone Liberal, Tory and NDP.

properties.name: Edmonton-Castle Downs
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamIt took a judge\'s recount to decide that Thomas Lukaszuk had won by three votes in 2004, while most fellow city Tories were swept away. 3Landslide Lukaszuk2 now faces the same challenger, Liberal hockey player and welder Chris Kibermanis, who has been door-knocking for three years. The NDP is fielding Ali Haymour, an on-leave Alberta sheriff.

properties.name: Edmonton-Decore
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamIn a riding so Liberal it\'s named after a former party leader, Tories have high hopes and some Grits worry about the fate of one-term MLA Bill Bonko. Former Catholic school trustee Janice Sarich is the PC; Bonko himself was a former public trustee. If Ed Stelmach1s coattails are a big asset for the Tories, this riding could switch.

properties.name: Edmonton-Ellerslie
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamBharat Agnihotri kept this southern riding Liberal last time by a mere 201 votes. The MLA faces repeat candidates Naresh Bhardwaj (PC) and Marilyn Assheton-Smith (NDP). Tories haven1t held this seat since 1982.

properties.name: Edmonton-Glenora
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamLiberal Bruce Miller, a United Church minister, took Glenora in a three-way dogfight in 2004 against a sitting Conservative MLA and the former head of the Alberta Teachers1 Association. His foes this time are less prominent: New Democrat Arlene Chapman, a former federal candidate, and Tory party executive Heather Klimchuk.

properties.name: Edmonton-Gold Bar
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamOne of the NDP1s highest-profile candidates is running here, former city councillor Sherry McKibben. But Liberal veteran Hugh MacDonald has proven hard to topple, winning one of Alberta1s biggest landslides last time. Accountant and community centre founder David Dorward is representing the Tories.

properties.name: Edmonton-Highlands-Norwood
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamHe has won easily before on his reputation as a bus driver, city councillor and now NDP leader. This time Brian Mason faces a former Liberal-turned-Tory, Andrew Beniuk, whom insiders admit faces a goliath of the left. Liberals are fielding Brad Smith, who placed third in Edmonton-Calder in 2004.

properties.name: Edmonton-Manning
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamMLA Dan Backs is seeking re-election as an independent after losing his spot in the Liberal caucus and then the Tory nomination. Longtime Grit organizer and lawyer Sandeep Dhir faces Mill Woods homebuilder Peter Sandhu of the Conservatives. Backs could split the Grit vote, but also the Tory vote with his pro-Stelmach message, while New Democrat Rick Murti may take votes on the left.

properties.name: Edmonton-McClung
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamHome of the giant-slayer â€¹ Mark Norris stunned Grit leader Nancy MacBeth in 2001, then pharmacist Mo Elsalhy knocked off the junior cabinet minister in 2004. Conservative candidate David Xiao has already proven unable to kill one giant, twice losing his bid to run as a federal Tory in MP Laurie Hawn1s riding.

properties.name: Edmonton-Meadowlark
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamLiberal MLA Maurice Tougas1 departure gives Tories hope they can win. Emergency room doctor Raj Sherman is their highly touted candidate, facing off against Liberal Debbie Cavaliere, a former Catholic school trustee. She had bid to fly the Tory banner here, but quit the nomination race days before Sherman won.

properties.name: Edmonton-Mill Creek
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamAssociate Minister for Capital Planning Gene Zwozdesky is the consummate constituency man, scooting daily from barbecue to community hall to awards event to four straight election wins (two as a Liberal). Liberal real estate agent Aman Gill came fairly close last time, and is confident she\'ll fare even better in the rematch. New Democrat millwright Stephen Anderson hopes to upset them both.

properties.name: Edmonton-Mill Woods
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamLiberal MLA Weslyn Mather is a former school assistant principal and perhaps the legislature1s leading children1s advocate. Conservative Carl Benito came within 518 votes of winning the riding in 2001, but that was when Liberals were at low ebb in the capital. Christina Gray of the NDP chairs the Edmonton Transit System Advisory Board.

properties.name: Edmonton-Riverview
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamLiberal Leader Kevin Taft not only doubled his party\'s seats last election, he also personally won more votes than anybody, anywhere else in Alberta. He had the biggest victory margin (6,705 votes) and the biggest percentage majority. This is his castle. Charging valiantly towards him are longtime political players Wendy Andrews of the Tories and New Democrat Erica Bullwinkle.

properties.name: Edmonton-Rutherford
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamEven members of other parties admit Rick Miller is one of the sharper Liberal MLAs. Up against him are ministerial aide Fred Horne for the Conservatives and Mike Butler of the NDP, entering politics as a social advocate after his wife was murdered last year.

properties.name: Edmonton-Strathcona
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamBased on their voting record, Strathcona residents will miss having former NDP leader Raj Pannu as MLA. He1s retiring after three terms. Stepping into his shoes is labour lawyer Rachel Notley. Other parties realize the legacy of her father, late NDP leader Grant Notley, casts a long shadow here. Legislature staffer Hughena Gagne was supposed to represent the Tories, but dropped out before the election started. Restaurant owner Tim Vant is running for the Liberals.

properties.name: Edmonton-Whitemud
properties.description: Posted by JournalwebteamWinning three straight elections as an Edmonton Tory is no easy task. Can Health Minister Dave Hancock make it four? This bedroom riding is Edmonton1s fastest growing, which means a whole lot of newcomers with no loyalties to Hancock. Liberals are fielding teacher Nancy Cavanaugh, who has been campaigning since last spring, while the NDP have Hana Razga, a recent Ward 4 city council candidate.
